author: {'steamid': '76561198133624401', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 40, 'playtime_forever': 3926, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3769, 'last_played': 1680283457}
review:
Blacksea Odyssey is an amazing concept for a game. You fly around space on a rocket surfboard, tethering beasts the size of planets, wielding spears and runes that allow for a host of amazing builds to facilitate a combination of tactical combat and twitch reflexes. Utterly unique from start to finish and bursting with original ideas like Willy Wonka playing Asteroids: Monster Hunter Edition while listening to Glory Hammer in the background. 

There is just one problem: everything I just described is so shaky that it measures on the Richter scale. Don't get me wrong - it is a decent game and I'm going to give it a recommend for just how many unique ideas it has. But keep in mind that unique ideas are often unique for a reason. And just as a pogo-stick made of ice cream or an airplane made of banana bread sound both unique and awesome - they are not structurally sound. 

Let's talk about what the game gets right: I enjoy combat. Very fun to fly around fighting a wide cast of imaginative enemies. Going up against some of the big bosses in particular and pulling chunks off of them until they look like they have suffered explosive bouts of leprosy. And I don't know why, but there is nothing like chasing down prey many hundreds of times your size and stabbing it to death with sewing needles that makes me feel like a legendary deep space hunter.

This game is 90% combat, 10% prep. But prep can completely alter how a fight goes. Maybe a particular set of runes are not doing the trick against the monster of the hour, but hey, swap in some water runes and the monster gets mashed. Which is important as a lot of the monsters you face are fairly beefy, with the kind of health bars that are used in gyms to rack weights for power lifters and small to medium sized forklifts.

The problem - by which I mean the problem around which all the game's problems revolve - is that the game is very clearly about luck, the runes you get dictate the kind of enemies you can handle, and yet the game is designed with the idea that skill is the deciding factor. I'm sorry, but there is no answer to certain enemies if you don't have the equipment to fight them. The most glaring example of this is when the game throws something like a berserk reefgoblin at you. How do you handle an enemy that is invulnerable to the front, can't be killed through raw damage, and can survive its body being ripped from its head - and STILL get faster? The answer is that you don't. Even if you boost, you run into the problem where your charged spear is slower than your character's movement - meaning that you've sunken time and resources into an enemy that just isn't worth the effort put into killing it. As the only way to kill it is to get a near impossible shot on a tiny fin going mach twelve and you'll suffer far more damage than any reward that creature can provide.

Even when an enemy is not impossible to kill, there are many cases where they are just tedious to deal with. Puffers, Angels, Starbait, Goblins, Sandchewers, and several other enemies are just not fun to fight and are usually not worth the trouble to kill. It gets even worse when most enemies in the later stages need to have their heads ripped off to have the common decency to stay down. And while fighting any one of these enemies is usually doable, every enemy comes in a group - often making dispatching them dangerous and tedious as you can't even position yourself to do damage without the right rune set up.

And that's really the killing blow. Later enemies just are not worth it. There is a strong argument to be made that if you're lucky enough to have your build sorted out you should skip killing enemies in the last couple rounds and just head straight for the boss of the zone, as engaging with the game at that point will always be a net loss. But even then, it goes back to the idea that even if you have your build sorted out, that doesn't mean you have the resources to beat the boss - as once again, some of the charging enemies are so fast that unless you are geared for boosting, you have no chance of outrunning them. It's to the point that playing against an elite charger boss is a flip of the coin. Sometimes they get mildly annoying enchantments like poison, or fire, or ice. But then you land on that 1 out of 4 chance that the boss whose entire gimmick is hitting fast and hard - you land on the berserk enchantment when makes the boss hit *faster and harder*.

I don't think I'm selling this correctly, so let me expand. There are multiple *normal* bosses that rely on use of your radar to have a chance against. You run along side them for a bit chucking sowing needles at them like an abusive spinster before they tear out of there like speed racer. But Berserk on elite bosses seems to increase their speed by some unknown percentage - and just as 50% faster on a tortoise just turns it into slightly faster tortoise, 50% faster on a formula 1 race car turns it into a interstellar warp missile powered by hate instead of blood. So by the time the monster shows up on your radar he is already helping himself to a space cowboy sandwich. I know at least one has an attacks that... well it isn't an instakill. It's more like an attack that does massive damage and can proc multiple times back to back that it is practically an instakill. It is the "I'm not touching you" of instakills. 

But these are all extreme examples. If you play the game right, prioritize keys and drop rates over everything else, and keep runes based on their future utility against certain monsters, then you're going to make it. But here is the problem with that: most of the rewards suck. The best character in the game is Emerald Jones - he is unlocked by killing one of the easiest bosses. The worst character is Xexemoth, and he is unlocked by killing one of the hardest. Even beating the game only rewards a mediocre spear. 

You know what the funny part is? One of the best spears in the game is supposed to be unlocked after completing the bestiary - this would require multiple runs beating the same bosses multiple times along with all the worst enemy types until you collect all 60+ entries. But by the grace of God, the programmers had a fit of good sense and didn't introduce the change - as such, the weapon Judgment is unlocked after only 20 entries. Far more doable and actually makes the early game fun past the first few runs. 

The wildest part is that Judgment isn't even *that* great a weapon and it would have taken one of the most tedious challenges to complete *AND* you would have no new challenges to test it on. I mean, maybe Elite mode - but you seriously have a better chance of beating Elite mode before filling out the Bestiary.

And that's still not the craziest part of this game. In the weirdest of weird moves, legendary runes are almost never seen in this game. Oh they exist and in the hands of a player that knows their business they can be very useful, but I know for a fact there are multiple players that beat the final boss and never seen one. Again, this is the dev trying to make the player feel like they have earned it, but i'm gonna be honest: unless that rune has the power to one-shot a boss, it is a little excessive to put 10 hours between every rune a player sees. I myself had only seen 1 or 2 in the 40 hrs I put in before I got the key spear and both of them, while powerful, were by no means game changers.

So with all these petty grievances aside, why should you play it if the rewards suck and the gameplay is generally unpolished, often breaking its own rules? To be honest, the biggest reward this game has to offer are the hunts themselves. Just the sheer spectacle of the 4 tent pole bosses justify the asking price. And just like I said at the start, it is a unique concept I haven't seen anywhere else.

Just goes to show: flying in a hurricane with an airplane made of banana bread is a terrible idea, but what a story to tell!

review:
Does the idea of Space Moby Dick and tearing apart giant monsters limb by limb make you go 'shit, that sounds awesome'? Then - but if and ONLY then - you'll like this game.

The ideas that Blacksea Odyssey are built on are seriously shouldering the entire thing.  If the ideas appeal to you, then the sheer visceral satisfaction of the part-ripping gameplay will offset the incomplete designs and dodgy balancing.  That's about the best I have to say as a review.  Even though I really do enjoy it myself, I'd give this game a neutral rating if I could, because the level of questionable design prevents me from truly calling it outright good.

review:
I honestly love this game to death. Currently in development or not, it's definetly one of my favorite games ever made. The way you battle giant creatures 100 times your size and slowly chip away at them, ripping off pieces and weakening them might be the most satisfying gameplayloop i have ever seen. 

As a fan of "death by 1000 cuts" styles of boss gameplay, I've had so many cool fights where i was able to flipp the powerdynamic after many minutes of dodging and picking my battles. One time i chased a giant stink-fly through the cosmos for half an hour, chopping of wings and weapons until it could barley move. I wish more games had that kind of satisfying "dismantling" of enemies.

Creaturedesigns are also top notch. If the kickstarter was still going, I would definetly pay to get to add another creature into the game.

If you're on the fence about buying the game, I'm here to tell you that the amout of fun you get for 7 ish dollars is more than worth it. Prepare to die, and you'll be swirving around, tearing out eyes and fins before you know it!

author: {'steamid': '76561198030784015', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11208, 'playtime_forever': 47, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 12, 'last_played': 1705779979}
review:
This is a lazy console ported "pseudo-retro" 2D top down twin stick procedurally generated "Shooter" with mild RPG elements tacked on.   The idea is that you are a future-retro space whaler with a harpoon, because the slaughter of endangered whales is somehow appealing to the developers here. 

Lazy low-fi South-Park tier paper imagery is used as a substitute for modern PC graphics, possibly due to either lack of budget or talent or both.  Regardless, the visual quality is woeful.  Gameplay is on par with the visuals, lazy dead console tier twin-stick shmup with a bit of grappling.  Half-Life, from 2 decades earlier, had better game mechanics.  20 years later, and here we are. 

The developer was unable to come up with decent level design or game/story flow/plot, so they opted to try to use samey repetitive procgen as a substitute for adding content to the game.  As a result, the game doesn't actually have any content worth mentioning.  Developers must learn that procgen is not content.

So we have a console ported minimalist twin stick "shmup" of extremely poor quality, with procgen used instead of actually adding story/content to the game, so what's the price tag? 50c? 25c?  Nope, $10 USD.  Apparently the developer feels this is the same value as similarly priced games on sale like Far Cry: New Dawn, Frostpunk, Mafia 3, and The Crew 2.  Think so?  Because I don't.

review:
If i had to sum this game up in short it would be something like this:

Easy life up to about the time you hit the yellow zones, then it turns into "Holy shit everything turns on a dime faster then i can move" you just end up in very much dumb looking marry go arounds while trying to figure out what part of the creature is actually hittable but most of the time you get get killed before you figure anything out  and have to restart since all you hear is the *think* sound of not damaging something. 

A lot of the longer enemies seem to have the "center" of them on the head, meaning the head is the part that just mostly spins around and the tail flies at beyond undogable speeds in the marry go around. 

Don't get me wrong, im not hating on the game for it being hard, an easy dame tends to be boring. But i dont think its hard cus of the right reasons.

My complaints are this:

- The jump from blue to yellow is far to drastic
- Creature turning should be adjusted to be a bit slower ( or at least dont have them turn on a dime if their front is armored...)
- Have it a bit more clear where to hit some creatures, specially things like the worms in yellow
- Have the shop actually be useful, the amount of times i have over a thousand or even 2 thousand gold simply cus there was nothing good in the shop is almost every run.

I might sound like a crybaby to some of you but games are meant to be challanging for the right reasons.

author: {'steamid': '76561198074848610', 'num_games_owned': 285, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 1692, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1634, 'last_played': 1672976713}
review:
Blacksea Odyssey is a game that, while an interesting and initially fun concept, fails at being a fun game.

One of the biggest points against this game is that it is abandoned in what can only be described as an unfinished state. There are items that literally do nothing (unintentionally), attacks that have inaccurate hit boxes relative to their sprites, and a truly severe lack of balance. 

The controls of the game are just bad. Movement is slippery and turning 180 requires taking wider turns than Euro Truck Sim; your spear attacks have very slow projectiles, making aiming annoying, and the boost mechanic is terrible. You use 1-3 of your 3 boost based on how long you hold it. 1 boost is so small as to be almost useless, 2 is usable but the cooldown is atrocious, and 3 is way too fast, to the point where your turn speed is not sufficient to stop you from careening away or directly into whatever you were fighting. 

The enemies in the game have interesting designs, usually a mash of two existing creatures, but sometimes angry flesh triangles. Unfortunately they're almost all spastic bastards who either fire endless projectiles, or are covered in armor and just try to rub on you, or both. Enemies also have a lot of health, so every fight drags on.

And, finally, the upgrades you get, the whole roguelike part, is complete and utter bullshit. You can get a legendary rune that carries the whole run from your first chest, or get literally nothing useful after taking down 5 of the 9 regions. Consumable items also suck, most last only 10 sec (a boss fight could last 10 minutes) since the bosses are so different, you might want a different build for different bosses, but it's so rare to get anything useful you almost never have a cohesive build, much less multiple. Unlike most rogue-likes, you have almost no interesting decisions to make; most of the time you have a bad choice and worse choices.

Overall, a frustrating and unfinished experience.

author: {'steamid': '76561198049498441', 'num_games_owned': 5263, 'num_reviews': 448, 'playtime_forever': 579, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 579, 'last_played': 1582989253}
review:
우주 사냥꾼들의 사냥 대회, 보트와 같은 우주선을 타고
검은 바다를 누비며 외계의 생물을 잡는 게임입니다.

부위 파괴로 일정 대미지를 주고 작살로 찍어 뜯어내는
부위파괴의 맛이 일품이라 다른 게임을 하다가도 생각나서 들어오게 됩니다.
로그라이크라서 운 빨을 심하게 타고 자체 회복 아이템이 나오는 것도 랜덤인데다가
소모 아이템도 별 쓸모가 없고 배랑 작살에 장착할 수 있는 룬도 너무 수가 적습니다.
라운드가 늘어날 수록 외계의 사냥감은 점점 악랄한 난이도를 자랑하는데에 비해 
사냥꾼들은 너무 구려요.

판마다 사냥터로 갈 곳을 정할 수 있습니다.
해당 판의 보스가 어떻게 되는지, 보너스 요소와 나쁜 요소는 어떻게 되는지 보고
본인의 아이템과 룬 상태에 따라 적절하게 안전빵으로 잡을 수 있는 곳을 가는 것이 최선입니다.

보스의 패턴도 악랄하고 보스의 몸이 단단해서 던지는 작살마다 튕겨져나오고 맞는 부위도 없고 하면 답답합니다.
보스가 나중가면 레비아탄이나 크툴루 같은 이계의 존재, 악마스러운게 나오는데다가 입에서 뭘 뱉고 쏘고
난리부르스를 춥니다. 게다가 크기조차 엄청나게 커서 제가 어딜 쏘는지도 확실하진 않아요.

저는 무력하게 꼬리 하나 잘라보겠다고 이쑤시개같은 작살을 날리며 데미지를 줄 뿐입니다.
피하기 힘든 패턴도 많구요. 부스터가 그렇게 효과적인 것도 아닙니다.
운빨 겜이지만 손 맛 하나로 이 게임을 추천합니다..

author: {'steamid': '76561198231493012', 'num_games_owned': 1075, 'num_reviews': 117, 'playtime_forever': 225, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 214, 'last_played': 1619655172}
review:
Developer walked away from this one before everything worked.  That's a fact and it's shameful and sad, because this is quite the unusual game, with a fantastic look, and it had so much potential squandered by an unwise dev who optimized it for a very narrow player group without thinking about the bigger picture, then left when sales didn't roll in.  If you aren't going to finish your game unless you reach certain sales goals, you do obviously have to make a game that will sell those copies.

That said, if you are that magical combination of tolerant to an unfinished product and looking for something where the easy mode would be considered brutally hard, [i]if it actually had an easy mode[/i], then hit that free demo.  It's definitely a weird top-down style shooter and pretty interesting to play, if just [i]ridiculously[/i] difficult to make any headway at all in, as even if it were finished, it's designed entirely for people who are already experts at playing it, and not really in a good way.

Note: If you're a mouse and keyboard player, I suspect the game is at least a little more reasonable, because stable aim-point accuracy seems like it'd be a huge benefit, and like many games, controller's aim cursor is way too close and restricted, which mouse doesn't suffer from.

Price history shows basically no discounts since mid-2018, so, much like with the bugs and things that don't work, this is what you get.  I'd like to recommend it just on raw uniqueness, but I didn't pay this much for it, and I'd not be pleased with that price if I had.  It's for such a limited player group that anyone buying it should feel properly warned.

author: {'steamid': '76561198060936212', 'num_games_owned': 367, 'num_reviews': 338, 'playtime_forever': 720, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 720, 'last_played': 1561581811}
review:
7/10

Забавно, что в игре нет ни черного (Черного?) моря, ни одиссеи. На самом деле дело происходит в космосе, при этом удивительно похожем на океан. Дело не только в условной двумерности, но и в обитателях - все космические монстры так или иначе похожи либо на морских обитателей, либо на прибрежных. Одиссеи, как странствий в поисках себя и дома, тут тоже нет - по сюжету это соревнование колоритных космических охотников. В общем, самым подходящим для игры названием стал бы "Космический Нантакет", но кто бы купил ее тогда.

Удивительное.
Представьте, что вы идете по своим делам, и вокруг вас начинает кружиться мушка. Все бы ничего, но она тыкает в вас малюсенькими иголками, а еще у нее есть крошечный гарпун, которым она отрывает самые истыканные кусочки тела. И так, пока вас не доконает кровотечение. Игра примерно про это. Только вместо вас колоссальные и не очень монстры, а вместо мушки - собственно вы, отважный космический гарпунёр. В общем, эта игра еще относится к жанру сражений с большими чудищами по типу Shadow of Colossus, но в инди обертке и 2D. Авторы грамотно выдержали игровой процесс - во главе угла конечно боссы, но ключевая прокачка и добывание экипировки осуществляется (по желанию) на средних чудищах, плюс, есть мелочевка, которая не приносит никаких бонусов, но порой портит нервы. В итоге, игру можно проходить как резкими скачками от колосса к колоссу, так и вдумчиво, перебирая добытые руны. Для первых есть даже спид-ран ачивка. 

Плюсы.
- Противники разнообразны, повадки каждого босса нужно изучать, порой ценой многих поражений, сражаться интересно и непросто.
- Руны и расходники разнообразят процесс и по сути формируют уникальный стиль каждой игровой партии; это особенно существенно потому, что выпадают они не так уж часто, особенно качественные, а выбор в магазине чаще всего убогий.
- Графика поначалу немного отпугивает, но потом привыкаешь и даже начинаешь ценить ее минимализм, не отвлекающий от геймплея.
- Идея с сонаром шикарная - на мини-карте монстры видны только при повороте сонара, а между ними перемещаются не всегда предсказуемо и могут появиться рядом с гарпунщиком внезапно и больно - это превращает игру в немножко хоррор, когда ты задерживаешь дыхание и напряженно вглядываешься в сонар, чтобы угадать, откуда придет опасность.
- Загарпунить Ктулху бесценно!
- Помимо Ктулху есть еще ряд литературных отсылок; первого доступного гарпунёра зовут просто - Старик (привет, Хэмингуэй!), а главный босс в конце игры - это одна огромная цитата из другого произведения (не буду спойлерить).
- Во время брифингов на станции персонажи забавно бормочут на загадочных языках.

Минусы.
- Музыка здесь просто есть, с геймплеем она гармонирует не очень, на мой взгляд, несет чисто служебную функцию озвучки спокойных и напряженных моментов.
- В игре очень серьезный рандом по обвесу, не каждая партия в итоге оказывается жизнеспособна (по крайней мере при моих руках); впрочем для хардкорного рогалика это должно быть нормально.
- Соревнование между гарпунщиками по очкам чисто номинальное; насколько я понял, я последним боссом имеет дело только протагонист, а за него должны отвалить столько очков, что можно перегнать кого угодно.

В общем, классный рогалик, в котором забег обычно составляет час, максимум полтора, а бои с противниками изобретательны и требуют индивидуального подхода. Я даже умудрился дойти до финального босса и поглазеть на него, хотя после просмотра чужого прохождения понимаю, что мне его не одолеть; пять фаз с условным буллетхэллом - это нечто. В любом случае, игра прекрасна, особенно срединным геймплеем, когда корабль уже экипирован рунами, а на сонаре маячит силуэт Ктулху.

author: {'steamid': '76561198035560545', 'num_games_owned': 3970, 'num_reviews': 224, 'playtime_forever': 268, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 267, 'last_played': 1622983786}
review:
[h1]  Don’t let the sci-fi erotic Moby  Dick  art throw you off. When the controller issues and bugs don't get in the way there’s some fun to be had [/h1]

(Herman Melville's classic work is censored, but i'm talking about the whale one obviously.)

Banksy's Otter Sea is commited to its setting. Instead of crawling through a dungeon you are hunting space monster bounties in a competition. This extends beyond narrative set-up for why you are thrusting yourself into dangerous monster laden territory: you in fact are competing, score-wise, with other a.i. Controlled  bounty hunters. It’s a non-combat element that can add some tension and healthy frustration to the game.

 In the prebattle state you can visit the shop, pick your bounty (the boss you will fight), and dig through your equipment and inventory. Whatever bounty you don’t choose is then assigned to the a.i. competition. There is some banter amongst the competitors, but for the most part this is your chance to gear up. 

Being tossed into the expansive, murky depths in search of a monster feels thrilling. Twinstick fans will find themselves right at home as the glide around and harpoon enemies. The movement feels purposefully weighted as you balance using your boosters , making turns and hitching yourself to enemies with your harpoon. Your primary fire consists of rapid fire styled javelins, while your alternate fire is the harpoon. While there are items that can lend some damage, your harpoon finisher is the preferred method for dealing with most enemies. If it feels like this has come up a lot, it’s because the harpoon is a defining feature: a charged up harpoon at the right time can rend a pulsating limb from enemies, weakening their damage output, slowing them down, or opening up new critical areas. It can be tricky to use at first, especially on nimble enemies, but when it does land, it feels great.

Outside of this one neat trick (space monsters hate it), the combat is standard fare. Your gear mostly just tweaks stats or adds generic effects to your primary fire and boosters: some split shots, critical chance increase, ice that slows down, faster attack, damage increase etc. There aren’t really any synergies or inventive options here. Obtaining these items is feast or famine as you rely on keys to open up chest that might contain credits, health pickups or gear. It is possible to get far without good gear, but even fodder enemies feel to spongy and quick in early stages, so runs will often drag out unless you get the right gear early.

It's worth a quick mention that bugs did cost me a few runs. Using a few different game pads I had some issues playing , but on top of that there were a few times that I got stuck at the shop screen or another menu and had to quit the game. It wasn't frequent, but losing a good run to some bugs is never fun.

The neat setting is conveyed well in game and a few distinct gameplay tweaks set this otherwise responsive twinstick roguelite apart, but it probably won’t rend you away from Dead Cells or BoI or whatever roguelite is dominating right now.

author: {'steamid': '76561198046528648', 'num_games_owned': 2315, 'num_reviews': 161, 'playtime_forever': 52, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 52, 'last_played': 1525035685}
review:
非常有意思的游戏。
总计9轮的宇宙狩猎竞赛。
每轮可以选择难度不同的狩猎目标。
含有不错的RL要素。
道具可以强化武器，船体，还有可以主动使用的道具，回血，炸药，护盾等等。

画面简单怪异，场景混乱的时候不容易花眼，也还不错。
各种宇宙怪物的造型到是很奇特，后面的大型BOSS也很有压迫力。
因为移动时有微妙的惯性，怪兽和飞船又在一直移动，武器的速度不是很快，所以操作上是有一些难度的。

操作：
WASD：移动
SHIFT：加速推进，可以撞碎地图上的岩石。
左键：投掷小矛
右键：投掷重型勾矛，再次右键将矛收回。
Q/E：使用道具。
TAB：弹出道具背包。
ESC：菜单。

小矛攻速快，伤害低。
重矛速度慢，伤害高，需要蓄力，可以扯碎身体部件。
当怪物身上有部位开始闪烁红光的时候，就可以用重矛扎上去在扯碎了。
小怪扯碎就死了，BOSS就要一点点撕了。

难度不同的狩猎地图，里面的小怪难度也不同。
狩猎前记得点右下角的SHOP购买出售装备，道具。
怪兽有时候会掉落钥匙，可以开启地图上的宝箱来获取各种道具。

BOSS不会直接出现在地图上，在地图上能够扫描到，呆在附近一会儿，就会从背景中浮现出来。

author: {'steamid': '76561198114721285', 'num_games_owned': 1853, 'num_reviews': 99, 'playtime_forever': 87, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 87, 'last_played': 1524840212}
review:
有趣的玩法被满地的肉山毁了，而且战斗手感也不太好。

游戏设定是，玩家与外星渔夫比赛猎杀海怪，比赛9轮。每轮有不同难度的猎物供玩家先手选择，然后电脑随机分配剩下的猎物。猎物越强，猎杀获得的分数越高。玩家根据情况来决定是硬刚大块头抢分，还是找一般难度的目标打钱、打宝箱积攒实力。

战斗设计非常有想法，玩家有两种攻击手段，左键普通投矛低伤害高频率，右键蓄力投锚高伤害还能钩在敌人身上，之后继续投矛攻击相同位置会打出debuff，再次右键收回锚就可以断肢了。整个战斗围绕断肢展开，一步步撕碎体型庞大的BOSS很有满足感。

但是，不知是不是因为我一直挑着难度高的地图打，敌人血量高得实在过分 ，更别说多数敌人都有几块无视伤害的甲壳，绕圈追着戳屁股也是醉醉的。玩家移动方式还有点尴尬，大概是为了符合渔夫打鱼的设定，驾驶的小快艇是单向向前的推进器+舵，移动还有惯性。于是在本来不算密集的弹幕中转向急停擦弹消耗的操作和精力反倒多了，使得较长时间的BOSS战乐趣骤减，这是我放弃继续挑战的主要原因——操作难和操作烦是两回事。

也可能是我衰老了，确实懒得在这种设计上死磕时间了。

author: {'steamid': '76561197999282226', 'num_games_owned': 972, 'num_reviews': 201, 'playtime_forever': 380, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 380, 'last_played': 1516843797}
review:
Blacksea Odyssey is a top-down shooter roguelike based around hunting massive leviathans in space, and collecting upgrades while you do so, hunting ever bigger monsters until you finally fight and defeat the Leviathans of the Deeps. The game is, on its face, fun enough, but after a few plays, the flaws in the game became enough to stop me from playing further.

The basic game loop is as follows: Start game, select one of four characters (one at start, 3 unlocked by beating specific monsters, each with their own basic ability), select a spear (each with its own ability - and some are MUCH better than others...), select a monster and stage (each monster comes with accompanying modifiers that affect the stage, like bigger or faster enemies, more or less loot, more or less keydrops, etc.), hunt monster, and repeat from stage select. While in stages, you fight small monsters, collect credits, collect keys to unlock chests, and then rip and tear the boss creature apart for a massive slew of loot, then go back to the stage select screen to buy other upgrades and do it again. Chests contain both consumables and rune upgrades for your ship and spear, as does the after-shop store, and is the only way to advancing your character. In this way, progress can feel very RNG gated. If you constantly get consumables, or get poor runes, or runes that don't synergize, your run feels like it's over before it started. The 3rd and 4th biomes especially take a massive hike in difficulty that can be impressive to surmount without synergized powerful ship and spear runes.

The game's music and graphics are passable (but repetitive - there's only one ambient track per biome, one combat track, and one boss music track per biome. It quickly wears thin, it's all grating and loud,, especially in the Desert and Abyss biomes), but what's really great is the sense of scale - you really do feel like a tiny dude in a space ship flinging toothpicks at these giant Shadows of the Colossus style monsters. Even the smaller random mobs are susceptible to being torn up bodypart by bodypart, and harpooning and tearing monsters often leads to weakening or changing their behavior in various ways, or even leads to quicker one shot kills, so it's always useful to rip off limbs. Ripping up the boss monsters is satisfying, and feels great, and is the core sense of fun in the game. Puzzling out how to approach and rend off pieces while dodging attacks is enjoyable.

The game takes a massive difficulty spike about half way in runs, when the desert and abyss biomes open up. The bosses are much more difficult, the game becomes much more bullet-helly, and even the generic monsters become SO speedy and orbiting around your ship that no matter what speed upgrades you have, you simply dont outrun them unless you use your severely limited (even with runes - but using boost runes when there are so many other important ship runes to use is folly) Boost to reposition. And if you don't have several well synergizing damage runes, the most important of which are spread shot and attack speed upgrades, you can be plinking away at even trash monsters for a great deal of time before you can harpoon bodyparts. As keys can be a rare currency, and chests will have consumables, only money, or random runes in equal measure, you can never really be sure what you're going to get - but unlike other roguelikes, you don't have the ability to fall back on at least being levelled up, you simply have underpowered runes, which can quickly end a run when forced to choose between 3 difficult bosses.

Ultimately, the game is fun. The final run of bosses are incredibly difficult and will test your skills to the limit even with powerful runes and consumables for you to use. Unlocking new spears and characters is relatively easy, and new unlocks come at a relatively quick pace. Monsters unlock bestiary entries with little lore snippets, and hints for how to better defeat them in the future. The game can become repetitive, since there's only so many bosses to fight, and four biomes, but runs are also small and bitesize, completeable in under an hour, easily. I wish more was done with the 'competitive' feel of the game - the game is set up to have you rivalling other hunters, but you never come across them other than to see their auto-generated scores and what monsters they fight. It would have been interesting to be able to come across them in missions and have to compete against them for kills or to score the final hit on bosses.

If you enjoy the top down shooter roguelike, and are intrigued by the tiny vs massive giant bossfight style, definitely give it a chance. Ultimately the amount of upgrade RNG you're subject to put me off of it, but honestly - I could probably have stood to get a lot better at the game, which probably would have mitigated my woes. A light recommend for fans of the genre, but for everyone else, you can probably afford to pass.

author: {'steamid': '76561198027977429', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 1172, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1098, 'last_played': 1640664527}
review:
Recently my internet has been going out and to give me somthing to do for the time being, i installed this game again to see if i was just bad in the past, or if my negative review was warranted. The TL:DR is that now that i have revisited it, I can say its actually bad. There are a couple reasons for this.

The entire game is RNG. The missions are random and its possible that you can get screwed by the affixes. Chest loot in mission is random as well as the chance for keys to open those chests is random. The shop is random after every mission. 

So why is this a problem? Early enemies are slow enough to where you can tolerate their janky movement and dont have enough health for you to spend your time on. Later missions however enemies will run circles around you if you dont have the necessary ship runes, and absorb spears for days if you dont have the proper spear runes. The only silver lining here is that there are a lot of potential builds that come from the spear runes, but as already mentioned, you may not even be able to round out a build by the time you get taken out by later missions. 

Enemies are very odd. Harpooning as a mechanic is fun, but other than giving a burst of damage, it actually just makes a segment of an enemy invulnerable. There is a tooltip in loading menus that says enemies are slowed while harpooned. The reality is that its not significant enough to be noticable. Not only that, harpooning pulls you AND the monster closer together, meaning enemies have an easier time hitting you because they are forced in closer. 

Probably the most frustrating part is enemy rotation doesnt seem to be tied to movement. Most of the enemies you fight are you continuously playing merry-go-round until they die, even after you have taken out things you would expect would halt locomotion when removed, such as jets for the squids and legs for the frogs. It doesnt help that hitboxes for the armored enemies feel inconsistent.

This game is frustrating and incredibly unrewarding. Its a continuous descent into the realization that everything is predetermined by RNG, and that there is no potential for skill to be rewarded in consequences or choices to result in game variation.

review:
There is a fun game concept here, but the implementation is lacking. A combination of frustrating design decisions and occasional severe bugs makes this into an unpleasant experience, and if one continues playing until one has beaten the game, it's more likely due to stubbornness than enjoyment.

In the beginning of the game, combat is tedious, a boring cycle of killing weak enemies that take too long to dispatch while waiting to find a weapon upgrade which may or may not ever materialize. Later in the game, most actual threats feel as though their danger comes from clumsy game mechanics rather than appropriate challenge. Various aspects of the game feel unpolished; a shop appears at the beginning of the game when the player cannot possibly have anything to sell or any money to spend, the visual indication of the boundary of the level is much too subtle, etc. 

Finally, frustrating bugs often take what enjoyment there is out of the experience. Sometimes, after finishing a level, all real progress will be lost; score is reset and items and upgrades are gone (seems to happen most frequently when alt-tabbing during level end). Some enemies can be rendered impossible to kill (an abyss enemy in the -goblin family has an invulnerable portion and a vulnerable portion; usually these can be killed by depleting their vulnerable portions' health and then harpooning them off, but a Berserk elite has enough bonus health to actually survive this process, leaving only the invulnerable portion to swim around and attack indefinitely). Finally, the game actually crashed after finishing the final level, so I have no idea whether there is supposed to be an end-game sequence, and I've no patience left to find out.

review:
ハントするボスを選択し続け、全９ラウンドを生き残るトップダウン+ローグライクゲーム。操作キャラとメイン攻撃であるスピアの種類を選択して出撃する。道中や店でパッシブ強化アイテムや使用アイテムが手に入る。
スピアは敵にダメージを与え、サブ攻撃のハープーンはダメージが蓄積した敵のパーツに打ち込むと剥がすことができる。
ヒレを剥がせば敵の機動力が落ちたり攻撃パーツを剥がして、無力化するといった事もできるし、慣れてくれば急所を剥がして瞬殺するという事も出来るのが楽しい所。時には、高速に動きまわる敵に打ち込んで速度に付いていく手法としても使えます。     　ボスはマップ内を徘徊しているので、見つけたらいきなり倒しにいってもいいし、アイテム回収などに時間を割いても良いです。コントローラーよりもキーボード・マウスのほうが優位だと感じました。BGMはあまり印象に残るものはありませんでした。ラスボスはかなりの長期戦になるので、ちょっとこれはローグライクで毎回戦うのがしんどいじゃないかと感じます。微妙に小回りがきかない自機キャラの操作感は評価が別れるかもしれません。
ボスの行動パターン、スピアと強化アイテムの組み合わせを理解し、初クリアに１８時間ぐらい掛かったので結構難しい部類のゲームかと思います。

author: {'steamid': '76561198032089697', 'num_games_owned': 92, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 75, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 75, 'last_played': 1491117905}
review:
Ah, the smell of the ocean, the breeze in your hair, the salt water splashing you in the face, such is the life. Ok I’m finished in the shower now on to my review.

Blacksea Odyssey by Blacksea Odyssey (no coincidence), has absolutely nothing to do with the wet blue stuff and all about the black void stuff, yes, space and the immense vacuum of it. Hack and slash your way through tonnes of baddies, at that’s just to get out of the saloon, not even into the game yet.

Story
Reading like a cross between Moby Dick by Herman Melville and The Island of Dr Moreau by H.G. Wells, you are one of the best hunters in the galaxy and in competition against others, you must find and hunt down the elusive White Whale or die trying.

Gameplay
I recommend to hit the tutorial first as this will guide you through your movement, fire and other quest keys. Also to get you use to the slightly weird use of WASD. Weird only because I am not use to it, but over time you can master it. W is to go up, S is to go down, A is to go left and D is to go right. Those using a control pad will be use to this. LMB is throw spear, RMB is power up throw (very handy) a second click of RMB will rip limbs off if powered throw is a success. Shift is power boost to your ship, if you need to do a quick get away or to ram some terrain out of your way.

You start of with the Old Man, who looks more like Neptune from The Little Mermaid, only more bad ass space marine style and a crude spear (you get to unlock three more Hunters and a boatload of WTF spears later).

You meet at the main Saloon and listen (read) to some banter from your competitors, some of it can scroll through a bit too fast, so brush up on your speed reading. Then you from a space map you pick which Monster bounty you wish to go hunt for. These will have a lvl of difficulty and bounty listed with them but don’t be fooled, even lvl 1 monsters will kick your butt, hard! Select then hit the road..um space.

You fly around the area, keeping a close eye on your radar in the bottom left corner, if a red ping shows then you have a monster near by.  The map is filled with space flora (shrooms) that can cause psychedelic hallucinations, so avoid at all costs. Also minor monsters that can pack a punch or swarm you to death. 
All kills will earn you money and points so hunt away, but you need pick you opportunity as most monsters have some form of hardshell armour and your spears will just bounce off, aim for the soft fleshy parts. You can power up the throw by holding the RMB, let loose and land a hit, RMB click again and you can start to dismember your prey, piece by piece (Calamari anyone!).

Some of your prey will drop coins and even keys if your lucky. Take a key and scan for a hidden chest, to claim loot. Most loot is power-ups for your spear or ship or both. Above all do not die as this is a permadeath game and there is no health boosts or aids unless in a chest. Once you have killed you bounty you return to the Saloon and rinse and repeat.

Everything else
Main menu and options are well thrashed out giving you options on graphics and sound as well as key binding and feedback vibration (for those who play with their controller between legs, you sickos!)

Graphics are cartoonish Southpark style, are crisp and clean and work very well here. Back ground music is subtle and upbeat and is not annoying so leave it on. Movement is crisp and very responsive, sometimes a little too responsive but at the same time it will save your butt a tonne load.

My only small grips with this game is that a) monsters can hide behind the space debris from you as you need to either blow it out of the way or go around, but you can hide behind it because monsters just glide through it as if it’s not there. 

b) It has a very steep (not steep, it’s a bloody sheer cliff) learning curve that even low level monsters eat you up for breakfast, lunch and tea!

c) Story is bare exists but maybe a bit more tweaking it could beef up the game a bit more.

Outside of these, Blacksea Odyssey by Blacksea Odyssey (still no resemblance) is a fun action shooter/Harpooner that needs to be in your library.

review:
This game is weird...but really quite awesome.  It is a bullet hell game.....well.....no....um well I don't really know how to describe it.  Certainly some enemies shoot poison or shards at you, but mostly they try to hit you.  You are a hunter, in part of a contest to prove who is the best hunter ever.  You are competing with 4 other hunters, who all take on different bounties.

Gameplay is like this;  you start in a square map in the black sea, you have a sonar on your ship, which can show you the location of enemies.  You throw spears at the enemies to hurt them, but can also harpoon them to slow them down and even rip off parts of their bodies to inflict massive damage and cripple them.

It is awesome.

author: {'steamid': '76561198042485131', 'num_games_owned': 1221, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 178, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 178, 'last_played': 1485547299}
review:
ROGUE-LIKE!! If any of you read my Eldritch review, you must already know I have a soft spot in my cold, dark heart for rogue-likes. It all started with the original Binding of Isaac, there Is something about the randomness of the items and your progression that appeals to me, and this game does that rather well, there is room for improvement, but at it's current state, it's really fun.

Many years in the future, The Galaxy holds a sacred tournament that happens once a decade, The Blacksea odyssey, in which every hunter must prove their worth by hunting down and killing the most ferocious creatures that exist in the known universe, in which the winner, aside from insurmountable riches, gets a chance to battle the legendary Titan of the Stars.
Well, the story is a bit lackluster, but it does add something to one of the characters, in which there are 4, all really well designed and colourful, and the one you start with is The Old Man, who is one of the oldest humans to still roam the galaxy, and he is in search of revenge from the Titan, who took his arm in his youth, and he is poised to do whatever is necessary to defeat the blasted space whale.
Does it sound familiar? It's because it is, The Old Man is basically Captain Ahab, from Moby Dyck, and the Titan is the whale himself.

The game is a top-down rogue-like, with Nuclear Throne like controls, in this game you've got two active item slots, a boost system, and spear and a harpoon, and an amazing combat mechanic, you can weaken the monster's limbs, and after they've been weakened enough, you can harpoon them and rip them off, which limits the monster's attacks and mobility, that is such a cool mechanic, and it works so well, it is amazing to rip off the bosses's arms and spiked tails, sooo satisfying. You can also improve your spears and your ship with runes, changing your playstyle a bit, and at the start of each game you can also pick one of the 4 characters and one spear, each of them with their own playstyle as well.
Also, every part of the map's terrain is breakable, you can use your active bomb items to blow them up, or just boost trough them, this prevents the enemies to pin you at walls and just murder you, which still happens at times.
There is one peeve I had with this game, some things clearly need rebalancing, your boost clearly needs to last longer, it's barely a boost as it is right now, you've got to use it to dodge the boss's attacks, but then it enters an ungodly cooldown. Also Megalodon is just absurd, it turns way too fast, Jackdaw needs to have a weak spot in his mouth, not just block everything. And the frogs at the early levels are really annoying when you still have no runes to boost damage.

The graphics are OK, there is a bit of room for improvement, but I like the game's style, the designs being what I love the most, every enemy has a really cool design which complements their fighting style. Some of the bosses are MASSIVE, like REALLY HUGE, they easily dwarf your view range, and I like that Shadow of The Colossus type of huge bosses.
The music is also kind of catchy, but I am one to prefer podcasts and other types of music while playing video games.

Overall, this game has the potential to be great, and as is, it's really fun, and the developers literally updated the game on the 18th, so it still has their support. I recommend it, you're sure to have several hours of fun with this.
Just remember to disable the screen shaking under the options, it's really headache inducing.

review:
A rather fun twin stick shooter that is highly reminiscent of Spore's cellular stage, with the premise of it being Captain Ahab in Space, murdering Cthulhu himself armed with nothing but a surfboard and a literal harpoon. How badass is that?
The game is viciously difficult and will not pull punches, but has been rebalanced somewhat by the developer after the initial releases, resulting in a far less frustrating experience than it once was.

I feel that the game still has some untapped potential, but in its current state this is certainly worth playing and enjoying.

Bear in mind, I initially had a negative review up for this game, with the strikes against it being poor balancing, glitches and my reading on the game's discussion section that the developers had abandoned it. The developer responded to my (rather spicy) review very calmly and patiently, stating that they had not abandoned the game and were working on a patch to address the issues.

Now that I know the product has not been abandoned and several of the issues it was suffering have been actively fixed by the developer, i'm glad to say I feel it has earned the ol' thumbs up. =)
Let's hope they can do even better - I certainly feel the developer is capable of it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198043854440', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 1341, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 732, 'last_played': 1485289492}
review:
[b]War of attrition: the game[/b]

On a serious note: it's, as you saw from videos and screenshots, game with shump elements (it's closer to western type of shmups, than to a super-mega-ultra-hardcore Japanese shmup) and rogue-like elements (random encounters and loot). So how does it work in practise? Gameplay cycle is as follows:
* kill trash monsters in their camps;
* slay relatively big boss monster;
* buy/sell loot;
* repeat this until the last battle against ... little bunny with a carrot-sword (not really).
Followed by item-stacking (or creation of build), heavy use of the surroundings, analysis of enemy behaviour patterns and other nuances that has to be learnt.

Man, I like the game a lot, but sometimes it can be kind of a "celestial dumpsterfire".

Pros:
* different space beasts with different behaviour patterns. One of the most impressive aspects was their ability to defend themselves in different ways even when approached from back.
* upgrades that require time to learn (like Pimpernel in Borderlands 2). Of course, there are your standard movement speed, attack speed, damage boosts, but that's just how it is.
* art style is great. It succeeds to deliver an atmosphere of harsh, cold and unforgiving space filled with creatures who don't give a damn about humans (it's a little bit influenced by Lovecraft's work (I know man didn't write about space hunter, but the feel is on some level similar)).
* most of the boss fights are really entertaining (at some level, at least, haha).
* environments are destructible and may be harmful, I really liked seeing debris drifting, awesome attention to detail.
* music is ok.

Cons:
* overlapping, disappearing and distorted audio (sometimes);
* bullet-spongy enemies; they can really be irritating, sure, if one has enough damage runes, the job can be done pretty quickly, otherwise drops are in the hands of RNGesus. So, I guess, it depends on one's preferences.
* some AI is really stubborn, especially that [spoiler]Megalodon[/spoiler]. Man, it is annoying, because that a-hole keeps on turning (very) fast when I tried to flank him. It seems that the boss does not have any turning limit like other bosses. Another example [spoiler]Vilemoth[/spoiler] - this majestic creature just flies around and do not attack me. I, like some kind of idiot, have to play catch with it. Not cool, dude, not cool. Also, some trash mobs (in void biome) are really fast - faster than my spear, especially when combined with speed modification. Jesus flippin Christ.
* this is where attrition comes in. There were some fights where I just gave up because battle became solid stalemate.

Oh, and I forgot, [spoiler]Doomreaper[/spoiler] and [spoiler]Aether[/spoiler], go to Hell, not to mention the last d-bag.

Verdict: game's between average and solid, in my opinion. If you are still curious or long boss battles are your thing, then sure, try it out. Otherwise - purchase if you have some "creds to burn". For me it lacks flexibility in dififculty, but I understand and respect design decisions.

author: {'steamid': '76561197968915202', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 380, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 380, 'last_played': 1483658699}
review:
Blacksea Odyssey is a highly enjoyable game.  [b]You should get it.[/b]

If you need further encouragement: Blacksea Odyssey feels like [i]Risk of Rain[/i] meets [i]Worms[/i].  It's a top-down Roguelike-like, with many unique weapon mods and destructible terrain.  The emphasis of the game is on boss battles: the end of each of the rounds is a boss that you select at the Bounty Select screen, so you know what to expect.  The stages between bosses are incredibly fluid, relying completely on your focus to advance and defeat the boss.  But even more than that, each mob fight feels like a mini-boss fight.  To defeat enemies, you have to focus their weak spots, then rip them off with a secondary-fire (a harpoon shot).  [b]This harpoon mechanic is extremely gratifying.[/b]  To me, this feels like what many Roguelikes (or Roquelites, or Roquelite-likes, you know what I mean) have been missing over the years.  I don't want to just beat shit up, [i]I want to make it feel like my shots matter.[/i]  I want to feel like a Master, more than just a Badass.  And Blacksea Odyssey does that for me.

In all fairness, I did encounter a bug that resulted in me dying.  But was that enough to make me want to stop playing?  [b]No.[/b]  (The Krakhammer boss became invulnerable, getting stuck at 100% health, more than halfway through the battle.  But I'm almost positive that the bug was a result of me pausing the game during combat, which was due to me jotting down a note of how awesome that boss battle was.)  It is likely that you will encounter bugs, but very few (if any) of these will be game-affecting.  Most are graphical or text bugs (I unlocked 135,000 chests!?), and the ones that do affect the game are forgivable.

And on to the polish.  The polish on this game is fantastic.  It's more than I've come to expect in most indie studios.  It's more than I've come to expect in games beyond indie studios.  You can feel the love the developers put into this game.  Background layers in stages, boss reveals, music tracks, character animations, destructible terrain, lighting effects on walls, character sheets, stage types, itemization, their spin on character creation, harpoon ripping physics... I could have a list a hundred items long, and still miss things that I appreciate.

Blacksea Odyssey is a great game.  I enjoyed it more than Everspace, and that's saying a lot.  You should buy it.

[I played this game using a mouse and keyboard.]

author: {'steamid': '76561198041967011', 'num_games_owned': 662, 'num_reviews': 536, 'playtime_forever': 1003, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 507, 'last_played': 1543396323}
review:
Ну, учитывая общий уровень качества, музыку и реализацию идеи Spore — можно похвалить, но огрехов многовато. Показывает 60 кадров, но рыпается, а настроек вообще нет (кроме звуковых). Управление не особо отзывчивое, целиться чаще тяжело и интерфейс не приятен глазу. Враги уже с первых уровней дают жару и против них нет приёма, приходится несколько часов к ряду дохнуть, пока научишься. В целом видно, что игра нуждается в парочке патчей.

Меня заинтересовали возможности построения билда персонажа, немного даже напомнило Path of Exile (в плане активных навыков). Конечно, тут всё более узко и просто, но приятно подано. Можно сказать, что тут есть оригинальность и достаточно хорашая подача, вот только цена в два раза выше заслуженной. Лично я брал в бандле, а там обошлось где-то в 20 центов. Учитывая, какой хлам пихают в Steam в последние пол года (2016), это был глоток свежего воздуха. Немного придётся потерпеть и смириться с недостатками, зато, думаю, оно того стоит.

Кстати, процесс ОЧЕНЬ напоминает Космическую Одиссею, а по ней качественных клонов вообще не припомню. Хотя да, даже та по сложности механик превосходит Blacksea Odyssey. В общем, на распродаже можете смело брать, если не собираетесь сильно придираться. Сложность довольно высокая, не Volgarr The Viking, да тем не менее...

author: {'steamid': '76561198050379221', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 62, 'playtime_forever': 2875, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2745, 'last_played': 1466636538}
review:
I won this game in a giveaway, but had I not I was ready to buy it. The videos and screenshots confused me a bit, but there was a free demo. Once I downloaded and started playing, I was hooked on hooking space monsters. If you are considering Blacksea Odyssey or even just curious, try the demo! 

You fly around through a series of levels attacking monsters and collecting power ups. At first it was difficult but I could see that with some practice and the right power ups it could be an awesome game. And it is. After the initial learning hump I couldn't stop playing and sank a lot of hours into trying to unlock new spears and characters and getting to further levels. 

Unfortunately every 2 or 3 levels the enemy types change and the only real way to defeat them is to die a few times learnng their patterns, which means you have to start the game over again, which means it could become unbearably grindy for some. 

Still, this is a creative and well-executed game. The combination of shooting and harpooning to rip enemies apart is a fun idea that plays out well, and there are lots of power ups and unlockabes to keep you hooked. It's probably best that I just end on that pun and you try the demo.

review:
The game Blacksea Odyssey follows the paths of four interstellar bounty hunters who "fish" in deep sea for giant monsters. Honestly, the story may as well not be there, as it's only told during cartrige-era text boxes, but for the amusing conversations that take place between the four hunters between missions, which if you take the time to read are actually quite amusing. 

As far as gameplay goes, you control your spaceship with WASD and fire with the mouse. There is gamepad support but I would recommend not using it. I've tried both, and even after taking a half hour getting used to it with the gamepad it still wasn't worth it. The controls simply don't work.

Your only customization going into the game is which of the characters you play as and what "spear" you use. Each one has different effects, pros, and cons. None of the bounty hunters are genericly better than the others. The standard indie random loot and infinite replayability rears its head here, with ship and spear upgrades being "runes" which are acquired by opening chests and defeating enemies. It's all comprehensive enough, although I've found the runes to be very unbalanced within teirs, and some runes are almost useless.

Controling the ship is a little clunky, as it controls more like a boat than a space ship. However, once you've adjusted for the controls and stop running into the projectile you were trying to dodge, the game flows very nicely and intuitively. 

Map design is a little boring, with four teirs of space and each one only having recoloured rocks. Enemy design is a little more inspired, though it doesn't take a genius to realize that there are about five categories of enemies and you just need to slot them in for each layer you travel to.

Now I will talk about the two biggest selling points of the game, which are the reasons the game is teeth-gnashingly difficult and extremely fun.

First is the enemy AI. Whoever did the programming for the puffer fish AI on the second level, hats off to you, I can never hit those guys from long range. Most enemies in the game have unique AI that determines their attack patterns, and it's enough that even after slaying a few hundred of the same enemy you can still be blindsided by their routine.

The second big selling point is the boss fights. There are seven levels to the game, and each one you get to choose which of a handful of bosses you'll be going after. Bosses range from insultingly easy (looking at you Puff Daddy) to basicly impossible without a perfect build (Charybdis). Almost every boss has some unique gimmick, and the level major bosses are as rewarding to fight as the challenge implies. 

I have a few minor problems, like the rune issue above and the fact that you can never just strafe to dodge those stunrocks from the level three bosses, but in the end the game is very solid. Not something to be played all day and beat, but a fun thing to do with a few hours to kill.

Oh, and on the subject of spears, I've been using the spear you get for completing the in-game beastiary, but I'm only done with 60% of it, so I have no idea how I unlocked it.

review:
I've never written a review for a game before, but the concept of Blacksea Odyssey is so ridiculous, and yet the mechanics of the game make it work so well, that I just had to write a quick one for it.

Long story short: Saddle up as one of four space hunters (You're forced to start as the Old Man, or Space Ahab as I call him, and unlock the other three by killing specific beasts) and enter a contest to see who can take down the biggest monstrosities in the void. Plays a bit like a shmup, but where most of your enemies are MUCH bigger than you, and your best friend is a huge fracking harpoon you can use to slow them down and then rip off their limbs/organs. Why, just before I wrote this review, I flew INTO the mouth of a giant space worm to rip out its eye ! No, I don't know why its eye was in its mouth, that's not the point, dagnabbit!

10/10 Call me Ishmael again.

review:
This game is a little buggy, but it seems that any game-breaking issues have been resolved. It's a fun twin-stick shooter style game with a fun ripping mechanic that allows you to weaken enemies (primarily bosses, but non-boss creatures often have rippable parts, too) and do extra damage to them.

The graphics are simple, but they're not unattractive. The soundtrack is good enough, but you'll be hearing the same songs loop frequently.

Be aware that this is a roguelike that requires multiple playthroughs to unlock content (new spears and hunters). You will have bad runs in which you won't get good enough gear even if you target the highest-bounty targets, but you'll also have good/fun runs in which you get great gear and wipe the floor with most enemies.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025452527', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 70, 'playtime_forever': 1596, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1330, 'last_played': 1466269921}
review:
The game is initially really appealing but it gets less enjoyable as you encounter more of the odd design choices that make it less than it could be - and then more enjoyable again as you get to know all the crazy stuff the genuinely innovative and fun gameplay has to offer.

Example of some frustrations, there's no confirmation dialog on the "Restart" button. There is to exit, but not restart, so good luck not ever pressing that. You also can't get drops from bosses if they're in the black, inky area, despite the fact that bosses sure do love to move there and die. Bye, all that effort! You get nothing for it!

Example of some awesome things, there's next to no limit on how you stack the assorted runes and spears you can collect, which leads to some crazy cool synergies and a lot of variety in how you play each run. As you get better at piloting and harpooning, you start to be able to really dictate the stages of the fights you find yourself in, dancing and zooming around giant space beasts as you disable 'em progressively further.

I definitely recommend the game. Don't be dissuaded by a few rough edges, because the core gameplay is really something unique and fun. A new kind of 2D shooter, it really stands out from the genre (which is becoming more and more crowded with decent-level efforts, unfortunately).

review:
Tried the demo, bought the game. Beautiful concept, beautifully implemented.

You are bounty hunter, one of a few that can be unlocked. You're in a competition against other three bounty hunters. You pick a boss that's got some bounty on it's head, prefferably the higher ones since you're in a competition. That boss is too huge to be killed by simple arrows, which is why you have to rip those bosses apart with a harpoon. You have 9 rounds, each unlocking you harder bosses, while you upgrade yourself with drops you find from chests, bosses, or from a shop you can access each round.

This is a difficult roguelike bullet hell piece of art, with some unlockable characters, many unlockable weapons, each with unique style of attack, lots of big monsters and HUGE bosses.
It's really fun. Really.

author: {'steamid': '76561198057697546', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 56, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 56, 'last_played': 1465165762}
review:
The controls are unituitive and while not "floaty" the way in which you move is just horrid. Aiming with any sense of consistency is impossible. These issues apply to both keyboard&mouse and controller. The enemies never move how you would expect. Many of the small neemies will have boost-like movement, but even while boosting in a direction they will slide left or right which makes trying to avoid them frustrating.

 The bosses are big, which they use as a selling point, but the camera doesn't zoom out, or follow your ship well enough to make the fight feel like you are fighting a huge monster instead it feels like you are alwways stuck on the undamagable side of a big wall. If you are close enough to see where to aim at a boss, you are far too close to be able to avoid attacks. Like, FAR TOO CLOSE. I found myself sitting so far away I couldn't see any part of the boss until I thought they were done their sttacks before going in to try to get a few hits in.

 I have no idea if once you are supposed to start weak and get better with unlocks, but your starting weapon's effectiveness is on par with in what, in any other game what would be disgustingly useless. The smallest of enemies takes maybe 3 hits to kill, but due to the first probelsm stated this means probably firing anywhere between 5 and 10 shots. 

 The harpoon is a cool idea for tearing away pieces of the enemies, which is the best part of the game, but the charge time and the enemy movement again make using it not worth the effort other than on bosses.

If I may be so bold as to recommend ways to fix most of the issues: Take away the turning your ship has to do to move, let it just move immediatly in the direction you want to move in. Fix enemy movement so that it is more predictable. When you fight a boss have the camera zoom out so that you can see the whole boss as well as the environment around it. Increase the width and damage of your attacks so that they can be as least some what effective.

author: {'steamid': '76561198152866740', 'num_games_owned': 131, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 4262, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3727, 'last_played': 1485100836}
review:
Настало время переписывать обзор. [spoiler]ОБЗОР САМ НЕ ПЕРЕПИШЕТСЯ...[/spoiler] 
Хороший, годный Early Access перешел в состояние хорошей, годной игры. Может быть, даже рановато перешел...

Сюжет таков: четыре лучших охотника на космических НЁХ всея вселенной собрались в одном месте, чтобы в соревновании, под названием "Blacksea Odyssey", измерить, у кого писька длиннее.

Цель игры проста: пройди до конца и, опционально, окажись выше всех в таблице писькомерства. У вас есть четыре разных персонажа, десяток копий и пара-тройка десятков рун, апгрейдов на копье и корабль. Конкретно здесь ничего примечательного. Рогалик, десу.

До уровня "годнота" игру все так же вытягивает геймплей. Каждый (ну окей, почти каждый) моб - это продуманная моделька, с частями тела и зонами непробития. Достаточно надамаженную часть тела нужно отрывать гарпуном. Именно "нужно", на этом завязан весь геймплей. Без этого не пройдешь некоторых боссов, а позже и некоторых мобов.
А про добросовестность разработчиков... На Early Access стадии они служили своему делу верой и правдой. Баги фиксились, контент как-то добавлялся. Что будет теперь - не знаю. В этом плане нас ждет неясное будущее.

Также нельзя не заметить, что игра вышла из Early Access'а. Потеряна та ламповая атмосфера, когда в игру играли пара сотен человек... Но это так, печаль олдфака. А настоящая проблема в том, что в игру с кучей народа набигут и читеры. Таблица рекордов потеряет смысл, если читеров не будут пидорасить из нее.
А еще, несмотря на то, что игра уже в релизе, багов в ней по преждему дохера и маленькая тележка. Если у нас больше не будет апдейтов каждый вторник - то это плохо. Опять же, будем надеяться, что разрабы не огондурасятся.
А что до механики жидкого вакуума и мужиков без скафандров в открытом космосе, то игре про охотников на космических НЁХ это можно простить. Если же вас это не устраивает, можете искать обоснуи в процессе игры.

Однако, если положить на все это болт и просто посмотреть на игру, которая у нас есть сейчас, то она определенно стоит своих денег. 
[spoiler]И все равно, релизнулись рано. Поэтому минус балл.[/spoiler]

Итого, 8.130205 Кхтхулху-берсеркеров из 10.

Can't beat the  game.  Can get about 3/4ths in, and then it becomes an insane hell of dodging shots and incoming enermies, many of whom are bulletproof except in certain weak points.  That said, I couldn't beat Spelunky, and I loved that. I never beat the Lamb, and I have over 110 hours of Isaac logged.  Just because I can't beat a game doesn't mean I don't enjoy my playtime greatly; I'm just not a hardcore, difficult games winning person.  Still a damned fun play. 
The upgrades are useful, the powerups are balanced, and the art style has been described, by me, as like 'They made an image of a monster out of lasers, and then it became solid and came to life.'  There is a borderline sadistic glee in hunting down the massive bosses, dealing out the damage as you dodge and weave, and then RIPPING off a fin or clawm and seeing a hunk of their HP vanish, and often suffer a loss of speed or mobility or a special attack related to that bit. author: {'steamid': '76561198019405086', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 364, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 177, 'last_played': 1529740464}
review:
When you first enter this game you might think that it is too corny, the character you are given somehwhat of a Space-Age "Ahab" who even is out to hunt "the great white one" just with a lost arm instead of a lost leg and cheesy banter between the contestants before choosing the monster to hun. However the moment you are dropped into your first match (hopefully after learning the few ropes you need to know) you embark into a randomly generated stretch of space and go out to hunt your target and see where this game really shines:

Every enemy of the game has weakspots you can tear and rip, most of which are giving it either an attack to hurt you with or which are essential for moving around. As you begin your first hunt you get to feel the first satisfactory rip and tear of an enemy's body while learing to maneuver the board you are "surfing" on. Once you have fished away all the "smaller" enemies (or if you feel lucky go straight ahead to kill the boss) you end up meeting the prey you chose only to face a creature that might as well hunt you down instead. The bosses with their elaborate behavior patterns, massive size and tons of HP are the bread and butter of this game and it is a blast to "hunt" them down. They whack you away like the fly you are forcing you to learn their patterns, evade projectiles and melee attacks while whittling away at often elusive and protected weakspots to tear them off to do more damage. This essence of studying your target and strategical approach makes for tons of fun with hours on end! Even if you bested the same boss over and over again you come back and the "worst" you could say is "Oh, hello old friend. Is it this time of the tournament again?"

As for controls the game is smooth and swift, the harpooning and spear-throwing going on without issues while requiring your skill to make the most of them. You HAVE items you can use, but one-use items are to aid in a pinch and are never able to one-hit anyone but lesser cannonfodder. They are all about strategic use which you have to time, less the item is wasted or even worse...you! Several spears (not harpoons!) to choose from give you another tactical element to consider which often goes hand-in-hand with the "runes" you find. They are passive bonuses which are divided into the "Spear" and "Ship" group which augment and enhance the respective aspect in many ways. Do you want some poison damage to slowly chip away at the bosses health since you cannot hit him? Do you want higher chances to throw more spears for bursts of Extra-DPS or are you so cocky to use a rune massively boosting your damage while you stand still? The options can be mixed and matched on the spot thanks to a generous inventory size so you can adjust to match every enemy with a tactc befitting him and while there are pattens it is you who sets the pace and approach every time.

To summarize, Blacksea Odyssey is a game about real "big-game" huntin in space with options to improve your weapon and ship while challenging you to take on more and more dangerous creatures with 4 different Contestants (3 Unlockable) to choose from and over a dozen harpoons. The closest equivalent would be a Monster Hunter meets Top Down Shooter in Space, although the customization here is not as massive. Taking bosses apart in a literal manner is fun and requires skill which keeps you coming even for bosses you already ended before to see how much better you have become. Fighting them is adrenaline inducing as you are likely fighting for 5 minutes per boss depending how well you do and things never get dull either. I have yet to notice a bug that affected gameplay and it runs smooth without issue and I clearly recommend this for anyone liking themselves some top-down action against big bosses round for round and a handful of RPG-inspired enhancements. Each run is new and yet not, old "friends" and new challenges surfacing every new try. Now get out there Contestant and hunt your way to the top in the depths of the Blacksea Odyssey.

author: {'steamid': '76561198188323877', 'num_games_owned': 223, 'num_reviews': 43, 'playtime_forever': 7101, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3055, 'last_played': 1572873325}
review:
Старик с закосом на посейдона летает среди космических рыб и убивает все что движется путем расчленения через гарпун.

Очень необычный, захватывающий геймплей. Враги принимают удары разными частями тела и если избивать только одну, ее нужно оторвать и враг получит очень много урона. Это необходимо делать для эффективной расправы с большими врагами, но с маленькими не обязательно (хотя о чем это я, такой шанс грех упустить).
Некоторые боссы размером аш с целый уровень! И как же приятно им отрывать конечности одну за другой, приближаясь к голове!
Огромное разнообразие: в определенных биомах - определенные враги и боссы. Перед началом раунда вы сами выбираете на какого босса пойти, с какого упадет больше плюшек!
Но некоторые боссы настолько суровы, что без специальных рун на них идти - суицид. И это тоже плюс.
Руны, которые улучшают лодку и копье - улучшайте атаку, комбинируйте, кидайте фаерболы и ядра, ускоряйтесь быстрее и много много других плюшек.
Большое количество расходников - вспышки, мины, бомбы, аптечки, щиты, зелья, стероиды - без них никуда, нужно использовать с умом!
Последние уровни не просто так последние - они реально сложные! 

Игра в раннем доступе, но выглядит потрясно. Желаю разработчикам поскорее завершить ее.
8/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198049478345', 'num_games_owned': 541, 'num_reviews': 192, 'playtime_forever': 1134, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 816, 'last_played': 1464112128}
review:
Разработчик связался со мной в твиттере(!) и подарил ключик, дабы я заценил игру. Впервые вижу разработчика которому не плевать на свой проект, продвигают как могут.

Про саму игру сейчас много не скажешь, ибо ранний доступ и контента не так много. В общем, играем мы за космического охотника на иноплатнетную рыбу. Оружие - копья, каждое со своими статами. Дополнительное оружие - гарпун, нанеся определенное количество урона части тела врага, мы можем её оторвать. Вы когда-нибудь отрывали  ж
oпу огромной рыбе? А Левиафана на куски разрывали? А Ктулху? В этой игре сможете оторвать и лицо и жoпу и всё что захочется. Причём отрывать не просто можно, а НУЖНО. Потому что доведенная до "загарпунивания" часть тела перестает принимать урон от обычных попаданий. Некоторых боссов можно забить и просто стреляя, но отрывая куски вы убьёте их быстрее.

Но это было бы скучно, если бы не руны! Да. Рунами тут усиливается ваше копьё и ваш корабль. Копьё может иметь элементальные (огонь, лёд, молния и т.д.) атаки, можно ставить модификаторы скорострельности или "снайпера". Для корабля отдельные руны - сонар, скорость, воскрешение, фаербол, пушка и т.д. Каждая руна имеет несколько степеней редкости  от Common до Legendary и чем реже руна, тем круче у неё статы. Короче рун тут очень много, я за 13 часов далеко не всё видел.  Так же у нас в арсенале аптечки, стероиды, зелья берсерка и прочие мины с бомбами.

БОССЫ! Варьируются от "изи-пизи" Мегаларча до Ктулху который может убить вас одним ударом. Размеры тоже варьируются, бывают боссы размером с обычного моба, а есть боссы которые буквально размером с весь уровень. 

Цель - бить самых крутых боссов и за 7 раундов набрать максимальное количество очков. Хватит ли у вас "шаров"?

Минусы есть. Это бета и тут куча багов которые то и дело вылазят в очередном апдейте, но e-mail разработчиков есть в самой игре и фидбек они читают. Нашли баг - пишите им. Общаться, правда, придется на английском. :)


Пока что не идеальна, но очень даже играбельна. Правда слегка упорота. :D

7/10

author: {'steamid': '76561197963981669', 'num_games_owned': 751, 'num_reviews': 36, 'playtime_forever': 86, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 86, 'last_played': 1458004464}
review:
If you're looking for a game to capture the magic of Ernest Hemingway's The Old Man and the Sea, this is probably the closest you'll get.  It's a rogue-lite top-down shoot-em-up set in space and you're on a rocket powered surfboard as you fly through the black sea (re: space) throwing spears at space-fish and using your harpoon to violently rip body parts off of these space-fish.

It sounds like bullshit but nothing I said is false or exaggerated.  It's all genuine gameplay and it feels awesome.  It feels great to rip the leg off of a giant space-frog and then finish perforating it with your infinite supply of javelins.  The items all add significant choice of how you alter your gameplay, and the consumables are all fairly interesting.  It's a fun roguelite with a creative setting and a unique aesthetic.

The description claims RPG, but I wish it were removed because the only remotely RPG-like feature is the inventory.

A few complaints:
 - the terrain kinda sucks and is frustrating to move around and is pretty dull in general
 - it's annoying/tedious to find things in the world because the sonar (radar) is small and local and doesn't show chests
 - some elements of the UI don't quite match aesthetically, so there's a weird disconnect (minor complaint at best)
 - the screenshots on this Steam page shows a lot of items but items seem much more rare than the screenshots suggest, leaving you starving for something to equip half the time
 - chests are very underwhelming for how tedious/annoying they are to hunt down

These complaints are all acceptable to me considering how fun the game already is and the fact that this game is in early access makes me hopeful that the devs will address these complaints over time.  And they've promised updates EVERY 7 DAYS.  That's awesome!

Blacksea Odyssey steam early access full review (this took me so long then I accidentally closed the tab and had to make it again XD)

Contains spoilers.

The bosses were incredible and interesting. Puff Daddy was far too difficult at first, but after I got used to him, it became a lot easier. Moonsplitter is absolutely incredible and my favorite design-wise. I don't know why, I just love him. Megalarch and Belch Brothers are great, and NOM NOM NOM?!?!?!?!?!? How do you come up with stuff that creative? Great Ghuza did not disappoint, Wyv the Elder's unique Tri-Breath was great, and Charybdis (I hope I spelled that right) was UTTERLY INCREDIBLE. I mean, the whirpool mouth insta-kill, the crazy under the screen tentacles, the vast number of little sucker-like poison shooters... I mean, I can't find anything to dislike. Here are my only problems. 1. Wyv the Elder has such a fast breath recharge that it's nearly impossible to rip out his tails. Also, his attack range is a bit too wide. 2. Belch Brothers are waaaaaaaaay to easy. 3. Can you even rip off ANYTHING from Puff Daddy? Enemies are all great, except for one stupid little bugger that makes my blood boil... THE SKITTISH LEAP-FROG. The idiotic little monstrosity looks great on the outside, but of the inside he's a green little ball of PURE EVIL. I'd take three belch brothers with my ship at ten hit points over five Skittish Leap-Frogs. Also, I continue to encounter a bug where my harpoon passes straight through enemies. Doesn't happen nearly as often with bosses. Getting stuck on tiny bits of stone or spinning rocks is a problem too, as well as me constantly getting blocked by weird, unbreakable invisible walls that harpoons and spears can pass through as well as enemies. Overall, this game has been an amazing experience and I am proud to have just unlocked Gungnir ;). 4.5 out of 5 stars.
